elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Two novel lanthanide MOFs, {{Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}[Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(L)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Tb, Eu), have been successfully synthesized as a bifunctional luminescent probe for detecting nitrobenzene (NB) and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions.</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0040">
<ce:link id="lk00040" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538717303200/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Two lanthanide MOFs, namely {{Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}[Tb<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(L)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {{Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}[Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(L)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), based on the flexible ligand 5-(bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions, where DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide. The two compounds exhibit a 3D structure with rectangle channels encapsulating [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations. The microporous structure as well as the confinement of cations inside the MOFs pores allows <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to act as dual-functional luminescent materials to detect nitroaromatics and metal ions. The experiments show that the luminescence of sample <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in DMF solution was quenched when the nitrobenzene (NB) content reached 2.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L and concentration of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> reached 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Two novel lanthanide MOFs, {{Me2NH2}[LnIII(L)]·3H2O·DMF}
n
 (Ln=Tb, Eu), have been successfully synthesized as a bifunctional luminescent probe for detecting nitrobenzene (NB) and Fe3+ ions.







Abstract
Two lanthanide MOFs, namely {{Me2NH2}[TbIII(L)]·3H2O·DMF}
n
 (1) and {{Me2NH2}[EuIII(L)]·3H2O·DMF}
n
 (2), based on the flexible ligand 5-(bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)isophthalic acid (H4L) have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions, where DMF=
N,N-dimethylformamide. The two compounds exhibit a 3D structure with rectangle channels encapsulating [Me2NH2]+ cations. The microporous structure as well as the confinement of cations inside the MOFs pores allows 1 and 2 to act as dual-functional luminescent materials to detect nitroaromatics and metal ions. The experiments show that the luminescence of sample 1 in DMF solution was quenched when the nitrobenzene (NB) content reached 2.3×10−2
mol/L and concentration of Fe3+ reached 5×10−4
mol/L.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0040">
<ce:link id="lk00040" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538717303200/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been developed quickly because of their potential applications in gas storage and separation , ion exchange , dye adsorption and desorption , catalysis  and so on. Compared with transition metal-based MOFs, lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have more prominent fluorescence properties for sensing due to their unique optical properties , which are derived from f–f transitions, that are known as the “antenna effect” . So far, various Ln-MOFs have been prepared for detecting pesticides , explosives , cations , anions  and volatile organic compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been developed quickly because of their potential applications in gas storage and separation , ion exchange , dye adsorption and desorption , catalysis  and so on. Compared with transition metal-based MOFs, lanthanide MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have more prominent fluorescence properties for sensing due to their unique optical properties , which are derived from f–f transitions, that are known as the “antenna effect” . So far, various Ln-MOFs have been prepared for detecting pesticides , explosives , cations , anions  and volatile organic compounds .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">It is well known that iron is one of the indispensable elements for life, but the existence of a mass of iron ions will cause damage to the human body . On the other hand, nitrobenzene (NB) is also a very well-known intermediate and can be used to make explosives. Its extensive use can bring about severe environmental issues. Moreover, severe health issues can be caused by NB because it is very carcinogenic. Therefore, the development of new chemical sensors to detect both the Fe ion and NB is highly desirable.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is well known that iron is one of the indispensable elements for life, but the existence of a mass of iron ions will cause damage to the human body . On the other hand, nitrobenzene (NB) is also a very well-known intermediate and can be used to make explosives. Its extensive use can bring about severe environmental issues. Moreover, severe health issues can be caused by NB because it is very carcinogenic. Therefore, the development of new chemical sensors to detect both the Fe ion and NB is highly desirable.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The synthesis of MOFs based on flexible ligands is of current interest because flexible ligands may twist to make the MOF structures more versatile. In this work, the flexible polycarboxylic acid ligand 5-(bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L), having two isophthalate and one benzoate group, connected through a triethylamine moiety, was selected as a functional ligand to construct luminescent Ln-MOFs. Two 3D lanthanide MOFs, namely {{Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}[Tb<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(L)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {{Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}[Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(L)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), were prepared under solvothermal conditions. They were characterized and structurally determined. The microporous structures, as well as the confinement of cations inside the MOFs pores, allow the two Ln-MOFs to act as sensitive chemical sensors. In particular, we found that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is highly sensitive to the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and NB molecule, indicating that the Ln-MOF can be considered as a dual-functional luminescent sensing material.</ce:para>

other properties: sensitive to the Fe3+ ion and NB molecule

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st030">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The ligand 5-(bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) was prepared according to the literature method . All other chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Thermogravimetric analyses (TG-DSC) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> under a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere. The luminescent data were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The photoluminescent (PL) spectra were recorded on a RF-5301PC fluorescence spectrophotometer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and methods
The ligand 5-(bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)isophthalic acid (H4L) was prepared according to the literature method . All other chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as purchased without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range 4000–400cm−1. Thermogravimetric analyses (TG-DSC) were completed on a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1 under a N2 atmosphere. The luminescent data were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The photoluminescent (PL) spectra were recorded on a RF-5301PC fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st035">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of {{Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}[Tb<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(L)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L (0.045<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.020<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and Tb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.012<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) were dissolved in 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M). The mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), which was heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h. Colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected in 20% yield (0.010<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, based on H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">29</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Tb: C, 44.79; H, 4.66; N, 5.40%. Found: C, 44.45; H, 4.54; N, 5.84%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3444 w, 3060 w, 2930 w, 2797 w, 1629 s, 1598 s, 1549 s, 1419 s, 1167 w, 1017 w. 787 w.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis
Synthesis of {{Me2NH2}[TbIII(L)]·3H2O·DMF}n (1)
H4L (0.045mmol, 0.020g) and Tb(NO3)3·6H2O (0.025mmol, 0.012g) were dissolved in 4mL DMF, 1ml H2O and 0.5mL HNO3(2M). The mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (10mL), which was heated at 100°C for 3days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5°C/h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected in 20% yield (0.010g, based on H4L). Anal. Calcd for C29H36O12N3Tb: C, 44.79; H, 4.66; N, 5.40%. Found: C, 44.45; H, 4.54; N, 5.84%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3444 w, 3060 w, 2930 w, 2797 w, 1629 s, 1598 s, 1549 s, 1419 s, 1167 w, 1017 w. 787 w.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st045">Synthesis of {{Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}[Eu<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>(L)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·DMF}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L (0.045<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.020<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and Eu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.012<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) were dissolved in 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M). The mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), which was heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h. Colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected in 22% yield (0.012<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, based on H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">29</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Eu: C, 45.20; H, 4.70; N, 5.45%. Found: C, 45.06; H, 4.33; N, 5.67%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3441<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m, 3060 w, 2929 w, 2800 w, 1628<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1601<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1547<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1414<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1167 w, 1017 w, 786<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {{Me2NH2}[EuIII(L)]·3H2O·DMF}n (2)
H4L (0.045mmol, 0.020g) and Eu(NO3)3·6H2O (0.025mmol, 0.012g) were dissolved in 4mL DMF, 1ml H2O and 0.5mL HNO3(2M). The mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (10mL), which was heated at 100°C for 3days and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5°C/h. Colorless block crystals of 2 were collected in 22% yield (0.012g, based on H4L). Anal. Calcd for C29H36O12N3Eu: C, 45.20; H, 4.70; N, 5.45%. Found: C, 45.06; H, 4.33; N, 5.67%. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3441m, 3060 w, 2929 w, 2800 w, 1628s, 1601s, 1547s, 1414s, 1167 w, 1017 w, 786m.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st050">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The single-crystal structure data for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the <ce:italic>SADABS</ce:italic> program. The structures were solved by the direct method with the <ce:small-caps>SHELXS</ce:small-caps>-97 program and refined by full-matrix least squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with the <ce:small-caps>SHELXL</ce:small-caps>-97 program . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included in their calculated positions. It should be noted that the guest molecules in the channels of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were highly disordered and could not be modelled properly, so the diffuse electron densities resulting from them were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON  and the results were appended in the CIF file. The asymmetric unit of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of one Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion; one L ligand is deprotonated as L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, which indicated that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is an anionic framework, and cations should exist in the channel to keep the charge balance. Combined with the charge balance considerations, TG analyses and elemental analysis results, the cations were assigned as [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, generated from the decomposition of DMF. The cations and DMF are not represented in the unit cell contents in the crystal data. The details for data collection and refinement are included in the CIF file in the ESI. The crystal parameters, data collection and refinements for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are collected in . The missing [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and DMF molecules that were decided by element analysis and the TGA method were also added into the final formulae of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography
The single-crystal structure data for compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ
=0.71073Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct method with the SHELXS-97 program and refined by full-matrix least squares on F
2 with the SHELXL-97 program . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located and included in their calculated positions. It should be noted that the guest molecules in the channels of 1 were highly disordered and could not be modelled properly, so the diffuse electron densities resulting from them were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON  and the results were appended in the CIF file. The asymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of one Tb3+ ion; one L ligand is deprotonated as L4−, which indicated that 1 is an anionic framework, and cations should exist in the channel to keep the charge balance. Combined with the charge balance considerations, TG analyses and elemental analysis results, the cations were assigned as [Me2NH2]+, generated from the decomposition of DMF. The cations and DMF are not represented in the unit cell contents in the crystal data. The details for data collection and refinement are included in the CIF file in the ESI. The crystal parameters, data collection and refinements for 1 and 2 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 and 2 are collected in . The missing [Me2NH2]+ and DMF molecules that were decided by element analysis and the TGA method were also added into the final formulae of compounds 1 and 2.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Structural description</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The two compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both feature 3D structures, but since they are isostructural, we only discuss the structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in detail. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> recrystallizes in the space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, the Tb1 atom is surrounded by eight oxygen donors from six different H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligands. During the reaction, all the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligands are deprotonated as L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> and adopt the μ<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> mode (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>). Each H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand connects six Tb atoms. Four carboxylic acid oxygen atoms bridge two Tb atoms to form structure like paddle-wheel SBUs, as shown in b. These SBUs are joined together with isophthalate fragments to form a 1D chain with a Tb⋯Tb separation of 10.3882(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (c). Finally, these chains are further connected by carboxylic acid oxygen atoms from L ligands in different directions to generate a 3D structure with rectangle channels when viewed down the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (d). The voids in the framework are occupied by water and DMF molecules as guests. The hydrolysis of DMF under the solvothermal conditions could generate the basic [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation, which has been widely reported . PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> per unit cell) comprises 43.5% of the unit cell volume (after the removal of the guest molecules). The [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation is encapsulated in the framework channels. Due to inserting a methylene (–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–) unit among the rigid phenyl rings, some rotational degrees of freedom are induced to the phenyl rings in the ligand, which provides softness to the ligand and makes the ligand more flexible. The torsion angle between the methylene and the isophthalate ring is 78.11(4)° and 83.36(4)°. The dihedral angles between the phenyl ring plane of the benzoate subunit and the phenyl ring plane of the isophthalate fragment are 73.42(3)° and 79.71(1)° and the dihedral angle between the two phenyl ring subunit planes of the benzoate groups is 80.4°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Structural description
The two compounds 1 and 2 both feature 3D structures, but since they are isostructural, we only discuss the structure of compound 1 in detail. Compound 1 recrystallizes in the space group P2/c. As shown in 
a, the Tb1 atom is surrounded by eight oxygen donors from six different H4L ligands. During the reaction, all the H4L ligands are deprotonated as L4− and adopt the μ8-η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 mode (
). Each H4L ligand connects six Tb atoms. Four carboxylic acid oxygen atoms bridge two Tb atoms to form structure like paddle-wheel SBUs, as shown in b. These SBUs are joined together with isophthalate fragments to form a 1D chain with a Tb⋯Tb separation of 10.3882(2)Å (c). Finally, these chains are further connected by carboxylic acid oxygen atoms from L ligands in different directions to generate a 3D structure with rectangle channels when viewed down the b axis (d). The voids in the framework are occupied by water and DMF molecules as guests. The hydrolysis of DMF under the solvothermal conditions could generate the basic [Me2NH2]+ cation, which has been widely reported . PLATON calculations show that the guest accessible volume (1418Å3 per unit cell) comprises 43.5% of the unit cell volume (after the removal of the guest molecules). The [Me2NH2]+ cation is encapsulated in the framework channels. Due to inserting a methylene (–CH2–) unit among the rigid phenyl rings, some rotational degrees of freedom are induced to the phenyl rings in the ligand, which provides softness to the ligand and makes the ligand more flexible. The torsion angle between the methylene and the isophthalate ring is 78.11(4)° and 83.36(4)°. The dihedral angles between the phenyl ring plane of the benzoate subunit and the phenyl ring plane of the isophthalate fragment are 73.42(3)° and 79.71(1)° and the dihedral angle between the two phenyl ring subunit planes of the benzoate groups is 80.4°.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">From a topological viewpoint, the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand can be treated as a 4-connected node, and a two Tb atom unit can be treated as an 8-connected node. According to the topological analysis, this 3D structure can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected 2-nodal net with the <ce:bold>alb</ce:bold> topology (e). The Schlafli notation is {4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">8</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">17</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>} for this net, as indicated by the TOPOS software .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From a topological viewpoint, the H4L ligand can be treated as a 4-connected node, and a two Tb atom unit can be treated as an 8-connected node. According to the topological analysis, this 3D structure can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected 2-nodal net with the alb topology (e). The Schlafli notation is {44.62}2{48.617.83} for this net, as indicated by the TOPOS software .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st065">Infrared spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">As shown in , the broad band at 3444<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is assigned to the stretching vibrations of O–H groups. The absorption bands at 3060 and 2930, 2797<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> indicate the stretching vibrations of the C–H group in the benzene ring and methylene in the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand, respectively, whereas the presence of strong peaks at 1629, 1549 and 1419<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is assigned to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for the carboxylate groups.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Infrared spectra
As shown in , the broad band at 3444cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibrations of O–H groups. The absorption bands at 3060 and 2930, 2797cm−1 indicate the stretching vibrations of the C–H group in the benzene ring and methylene in the H4L ligand, respectively, whereas the presence of strong peaks at 1629, 1549 and 1419cm−1 is assigned to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for the carboxylate groups.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st070">Thermal analysis and PXRD pattern</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was performed to characterize their purity (). Most of the diffraction peaks on the experimental curves coincided with the simulated ones, except for some at the low angles, which may be attributed to the contribution from solvent DMF molecules or [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations in the channel. To estimate the stability of the coordination polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals over the 27–700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C range under a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the weight loss in the range 27–102<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is attributed to the release three lattice water molecules (obsd 7.0%, calcd 6.9%). When the temperature reaches about 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the weight loss is 15.4%, corresponding to the remove of DMF and [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (calcd 9.4 and 5.9%, respectively) . The TGA of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is similar to that of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis and PXRD pattern
Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) for compounds 1 and 2 was performed to characterize their purity (). Most of the diffraction peaks on the experimental curves coincided with the simulated ones, except for some at the low angles, which may be attributed to the contribution from solvent DMF molecules or [Me2NH2]+ cations in the channel. To estimate the stability of the coordination polymers 1 and 2, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals over the 27–700°C range under a N2 atmosphere. For compound 1, the weight loss in the range 27–102°C is attributed to the release three lattice water molecules (obsd 7.0%, calcd 6.9%). When the temperature reaches about 240°C, the weight loss is 15.4%, corresponding to the remove of DMF and [Me2NH2]+ (calcd 9.4 and 5.9%, respectively) . The TGA of compound 2 is similar to that of compound 1.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st075">Photoluminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The luminescent spectra of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were determined in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>. When excited at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> =<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, four characteristic emission bands for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>488, 545, 582 and 621<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm were displayed, which correspond to energy transfer of the Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions of <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>, <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, and <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, respectively. The characteristic transitions of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 593, 616, 654 and 702<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm are attributed to the <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> transitions, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence properties
The luminescent spectra of compounds 1 and 2 were determined in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in 
. When excited at λ =360nm, four characteristic emission bands for 1 at λ
=488, 545, 582 and 621nm were displayed, which correspond to energy transfer of the Tb3+ ions of 5D4→7F6, 5D4→7F5, 5D4→7F4, and 5D4→7F3, respectively. The characteristic transitions of compound 2 at 593, 616, 654 and 702nm are attributed to the 5D0→7F1, 5D0→7F2, 5D0→7F3 and 5D0→7F4 transitions, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st080">Solvent sensing</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">To examine the potential sensing for small solvent molecules, the fluorescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in different solvent emulsions were investigated. The samples were ground and immersed in different pure solvents for one day, treated by ultrasonication for over 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and then aged for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>day to form a stable emulsion before the fluorescence study. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the PL spectra are largely dependent on the solvent molecules. In the case of DMF and NB, the spectra exhibit enhanced or quenched behavior. To examine sensing sensitivity toward NB in detail, a batch of emulsions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in DMF solution with gradually increased NB contents were prepared to monitor the emissive response. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, the fluorescence intensity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> decreased gradually with the increasing NB concentration (from 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> to 2.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L), and it was completely quenched at 2.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L. A plot of the relative luminescent intensity (I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I) versus the concentration of nitrobenzene is shown in , where <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>I</ce:italic> are the luminescent intensities of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> before and after adding nitrobenzene, respectively. The plot cannot be well fitted by the Stern–Volmer equation, indicating the coexistence of dynamic and static quenching processes . The non-linear Stern–Volmer curve can be well-fitted by the exponential equation I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.83e<ce:sup loc="post">89[NB]</ce:sup>-4.55 with a quenching constant of 4.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> in the low concentration range .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Solvent sensing
To examine the potential sensing for small solvent molecules, the fluorescence properties of 1 in different solvent emulsions were investigated. The samples were ground and immersed in different pure solvents for one day, treated by ultrasonication for over 30min and then aged for 1day to form a stable emulsion before the fluorescence study. As shown in 
, the PL spectra are largely dependent on the solvent molecules. In the case of DMF and NB, the spectra exhibit enhanced or quenched behavior. To examine sensing sensitivity toward NB in detail, a batch of emulsions of 1 dispersed in DMF solution with gradually increased NB contents were prepared to monitor the emissive response. As shown in 
, the fluorescence intensity of 1 decreased gradually with the increasing NB concentration (from 4×10−3 to 2.3×10−2
mol/L), and it was completely quenched at 2.3×10−2
mol/L. A plot of the relative luminescent intensity (I0/I) versus the concentration of nitrobenzene is shown in , where I
0 and I are the luminescent intensities of compound 1 before and after adding nitrobenzene, respectively. The plot cannot be well fitted by the Stern–Volmer equation, indicating the coexistence of dynamic and static quenching processes . The non-linear Stern–Volmer curve can be well-fitted by the exponential equation I0/I=4.83e89[NB]-4.55 with a quenching constant of 4.3×102 in the low concentration range .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Electron transfer is capable of taking place upon excitation from the electron-donating framework to the high electron-withdrawing –NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group of the nitrobenzene unit, resulting in detectable luminescence quenching. Further examination of the stability of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> treated with NB was tested with PXRD (). The results show that the framework retains the structural integrity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Electron transfer is capable of taking place upon excitation from the electron-donating framework to the high electron-withdrawing –NO2 group of the nitrobenzene unit, resulting in detectable luminescence quenching. Further examination of the stability of compound 1 treated with NB was tested with PXRD (). The results show that the framework retains the structural integrity.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st085">Ion detection</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">As mentioned before, the structural feature of the [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation being encapsulated in the channels is advantageous for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to detect metal ions. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was ground and immersed in DMF solvent containing different amounts of M(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, Ag<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ca<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>) to form the samples M<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>@<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for luminescence studies. The concentration of the nitrate solution was 0.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L. As shown in the 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion exhibits drastic quenching effect on the luminescence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, while the other metal ions have no significant effect on the emission, with the exception of the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion, which can weaken the luminescence to some extent. In further experiments, we have examined the detection of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in detail. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>a and b, the fluorescence intensity of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>@<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> decreased gradually and drastically with increasing Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion concentration (from 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−5</ce:sup> to 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L), and the luminescence was quenched completely when the concentration of the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion reached 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L. To further study the relationship between the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion concentration and quenching effect, a plot of the luminescence intensity versus Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion concentration was made (). The luminescent intensity of different concentrations of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions obeys the equation I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.64e<ce:sup loc="post">7410[Fe3+]</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.24 with the quenching constant of 4.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> at low concentrations .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Ion detection
As mentioned before, the structural feature of the [Me2NH2]+ cation being encapsulated in the channels is advantageous for 1 to detect metal ions. Compound 1 was ground and immersed in DMF solvent containing different amounts of M(NO3)
x
 (M=K+, Ag+, Zn2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Pb2+, Ca2+, Cd2+, Cu2+ and Fe3+) to form the samples M
n

+@1 for luminescence studies. The concentration of the nitrate solution was 0.01mol/L. As shown in the 
, the Fe3+ ion exhibits drastic quenching effect on the luminescence of 1, while the other metal ions have no significant effect on the emission, with the exception of the Cu2+ ion, which can weaken the luminescence to some extent. In further experiments, we have examined the detection of Fe3+ ions in detail. As shown in 
a and b, the fluorescence intensity of Fe3+@1 decreased gradually and drastically with increasing Fe3+ ion concentration (from 5×10−5 to 5×10−4
mol/L), and the luminescence was quenched completely when the concentration of the Fe3+ ion reached 5×10−4
mol/L. To further study the relationship between the Fe3+ ion concentration and quenching effect, a plot of the luminescence intensity versus Fe3+ ion concentration was made (). The luminescent intensity of different concentrations of Fe3+ ions obeys the equation I0/I=0.64e7410[Fe3+]
+0.24 with the quenching constant of 4.7×103 at low concentrations .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Up until now, a number of MOFs have been successfully applied for the sensing of small molecules and ions, the results of which are summarized in 
. For example, Bharadwaj and co-workers used Tb-MOFs to detect both the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and NB molecule. The luminescence of the sample was quenched when the NB content reached 10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L and the concentration of the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion reached 10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> mol/L . Xu synthesize a chiral Tb-MOF to detect the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion; when the concentration was 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L, the quenching efficiency almost reached 100% . Liu reported new Zn-MOFs for sensing NB, and this type of NB probe can reach 5000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm . Most of the reported MOFs can detect Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions with concentrations from 10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> to 10<ce:sup loc="post">−5</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L. Comparably, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a relatively similar sensitivity and selectivity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Up until now, a number of MOFs have been successfully applied for the sensing of small molecules and ions, the results of which are summarized in 
. For example, Bharadwaj and co-workers used Tb-MOFs to detect both the Fe3+ ion and NB molecule. The luminescence of the sample was quenched when the NB content reached 10−4
mol/L and the concentration of the Fe3+ ion reached 10−2 mol/L . Xu synthesize a chiral Tb-MOF to detect the Fe3+ ion; when the concentration was 3×10−3
mol/L, the quenching efficiency almost reached 100% . Liu reported new Zn-MOFs for sensing NB, and this type of NB probe can reach 5000ppm . Most of the reported MOFs can detect Fe3+ ions with concentrations from 10−3 to 10−5
mol/L. Comparably, 1 exhibits a relatively similar sensitivity and selectivity.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">We speculate that the detection of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions might be related to the interaction between the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and the terminal Lewis basic sites and/or the carboxylate group sites in the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Such interactions reduce the energy transfer efficiency from the organic ligand to the Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions within its structure, therefore decreasing the luminescent intensity . The color changes of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with different concentrations of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions were recorded in . Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can still retain its framework after immersion in a DMF solution of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, which can be proven by PXRD patterns ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We speculate that the detection of Fe3+ ions might be related to the interaction between the Fe3+ ion and the terminal Lewis basic sites and/or the carboxylate group sites in the structure of 1. Such interactions reduce the energy transfer efficiency from the organic ligand to the Tb3+ ions within its structure, therefore decreasing the luminescent intensity . The color changes of compound 1 with different concentrations of Fe3+ ions were recorded in . Compound 1 can still retain its framework after immersion in a DMF solution of Fe3+ ions, which can be proven by PXRD patterns ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st090">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In this contribution, two lanthanide anionic frameworks with flexible polycarboxylic acid ligands have been synthesized. The two compounds are isostructural and exhibit a 3D structure with rectangle channels encapsulating [Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations, displaying a (4,8)-connected 2-nodal net with a <ce:bold>alb</ce:bold> topological network. The luminescence of sample <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in DMF solution was quenched when the NB content reached 2.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L and the concentration of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions reached 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L, which may allow it to be used as a bifunctional luminescent probe.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In this contribution, two lanthanide anionic frameworks with flexible polycarboxylic acid ligands have been synthesized. The two compounds are isostructural and exhibit a 3D structure with rectangle channels encapsulating [Me2NH2]+ cations, displaying a (4,8)-connected 2-nodal net with a alb topological network. The luminescence of sample 1 in DMF solution was quenched when the NB content reached 2.3×10−2
mol/L and the concentration of Fe3+ ions reached 5×10−4
mol/L, which may allow it to be used as a bifunctional luminescent probe.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st100">Supplementary data</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Additional crystallographic data for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in CIF format, TGA, PXRD and IR in PDF format. Crystallographic data of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC Nos 1524171 and 1524172, which can be obtained free of charge at <ce:inter-ref id="ir005" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html</ce:inter-ref> or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK, e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary data
Additional crystallographic data for compounds 1 and 2 in CIF format, TGA, PXRD and IR in PDF format. Crystallographic data of compounds 1 and 2 have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC Nos 1524171 and 1524172, which can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12, Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK, e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk. Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version.

elements.content:

metadata.title: Dual functional three-dimensional LnMOFs for luminescence sensing of nitrobenzene and Fe3+ ions
